Thanks Ken. I was guessing the same thing based on (1). I can't think of an=
y
good reason at the moment why crossover would help/hurt HyperNEAT more th=
an
P-NEAT. 

(2) surprises me, however. Isn't one of the hallmarks of NEAT =
the
intelligent crossover via historical markings? I guess I just assumed t=
hat
had been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover doesn't help that=
 much
in NEAT, how much does *intelligent* (vs. na=EFve) crossover help?


=



Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

we have not re-run the experiments yet I cannot say for sure,
> but I would=
 guess the effect to be minimal because (1) both HyperNEAT
> and PNEAT ran =
under same condition and (2) prior experiments have
> shown crossover in NE=
AT to improve performance marginally but not
> dramatically.
> 
> ken

>>> Hey Jeff,
>>> 
>>> Yeah, it looks like you=
 hit the nail on the head.  Right now, it
>>> either completely chooses one=
 parent or the other, but putting that
>>> code inside of the loop will mak=
e it treat each gene individually
>>> (this will perform real crossover).
>=
>> 
>>> I'm going to put in the change and see how it changes my experiment=
s.
>>>  Assuming it doesn't break anything, I'll roll this into the next
>>=
> version.  If it affects the results in a negative way, I'll make a
>>> pa=
rameter for it so you can choose to use crossover or not.
>>> 
>>> Thanks f=
or the find!
>>>

>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@=
> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>>> Well yes this is exactly what it has to be. Note that
=
> randomChoice has
>>>>> to be random every time you refer to it. If it is =
not random (i.e.
>>>>> outside the big loop) then you choose links from eit=
her parent.
> But if
>>>>> it is inside the loop, then you choose a gene ra=
ndomly from either
>>>>> parent. Check this out and you will have a clearer=
 picture if
> there is
>>>>> a bug or not.
>>>> 
>>>> Thanks Petar. I am co=
nfident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the parent
>>> outside
>>>> the loop, an=
d thus grabs all links from either parent1 or parent2.
>>> What I am
>>>> t=
rying to find out is whether this is by design, or if it is a bug.
>>>> 
>>=
>> Do you (or anyone else) happen to know how it works in other NEAT
>>> pa=
ckages,
>>>> in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My guess is that we ar=
e
>>> supposed to
>>>> be grabbing some links from parent1 and some other l=
inks from
> parent2,
>>>> instead of one or the other. I can go check those=
 packages, of
>>> course, but I
>>>> won't be able to do that for a little =
while and was wondering if any
>>> of you
>>>> knew off the top of your hea=
ds.
>>>> 
>>>>> But the cloning issue is a deeper one. In this case you mus=
t ensure
>>>>> that individuals should not mate with themselves or such one=
s that
>>>>> have zero compatibility distance. Or at least try a few hundre=
d
> times
>>>>> to find a different mate :) Hey, I say this to all users. D=
on't use
>>>>> rand(), fuck that, use the Mersenne Twister instead. I notic=
ed
> that in
>>>>> enhances performance!
>>>> 
>>>> Fair enough, but right =
now I am more focused on the more
> immediate issue
>>>> above. Thanks for =
the suggestions, though. I will delve into them
> when I
>>>> resolve the o=
ther issue.
>>>> 
>>>> Thanks. Jeff. 
>>>>> 
>>>>> Peter
>>>>> 
>>>>> --- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Hi Petar=
-
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Thanks for the reply. I do not have a (non-HyperNEAT) NEAT=
 package
>>>>> around.
>>>>>> Can you let me know if your NEAT implementati=
on is different than
>>>>> what I
>>>>>> report below?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I am =
using Jason's HyperNEAT 2.5 package available here:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> http://e=
plex.cs.ucf.edu/software.html
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> If you download the package, t=
he key file is:
>>>>>> HyperNEAT/NEAT/src/NEAT_GeneticIndividual.cpp
>>>>>>=
 
>>>>>> I am attaching it, but I don't know how that works with the yahoo
=
>>>>> group.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Crossover occurs in this constructor:
>>>>>> 
>=
>>>>>     
>>>>> GeneticIndividual::GeneticIndividual(shared_ptr<GeneticInd=
ividual>
>>>>>> parent1,shared_ptr<GeneticIndividual> parent2,bool
>>>>> ma=
te_multipoint_avg)
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> The following line occurs outside of the =
loop that goes through
> each
>>>>> link:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>  bool chooseFirstP=
arent =3D (randomChoice<=3Dparent1->getFitness());
>>>>>>  
>>>>>> Then, in=
side the loop for each link:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>                     if (chooseF=
irstParent)
>>>>>>                     {
>>>>>>                         add=
Link(GeneticLinkGene(*link1));
>>>>>>                     }
>>>>>>         =
            else
>>>>>>                     {
>>>>>>                       =
  addLink(GeneticLinkGene(*link2));
>>>>>>                     }
>>>>>>  
>=
>>>>> So, it seems that *all* the links will be grabbed from one
> parent o=
r
>>>>> the
>>>>>> other. Is that how it works in other versions of NEAT?

te: Sun, 09 Nov 2008 20:14:32 -0000

t@yahoogroups.com>
>>>>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in =
HyperNEAT and
>>>>> PNEAT?
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Hi Jeff, 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Well=
 I don't know about the exact implementations of HyperNEAT you
>>>>> are
>>=
>>>>> using (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
>>>>>>> =
disabled), but in principle crossover should choose genes randomly
>>>>>>> =
from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the child. In
>>>>>>> =
HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
>>>>> regular=

>>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other networks based on the
=
>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you only mate and mutate the
>>>>=
> CPPNs.
>>>>>>> But in the case you get lots of individuals with equal fit=
ness, I
>>>>>>> guess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the code freque=
ntly
>>>>>>> chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try to avoid =
this
>>>>> by
>>>>>>> introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a =
"father" that
>>>>> are
>>>>>>> not compatible with the mother, that is, wh=
en their compatibility
>>>>>>> distance is 0.00, try again. There is anothe=
r possibility, simply
>>>>>>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefor=
e the produced
>>>>> network is
>>>>>>> changed in such a magnitude that is=
 has no chance for survival and
>>>>> is
>>>>>>> discarded. Even though the=
re is speciation.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Peter
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> --- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Hello a=
ll-
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
>=
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
>>>>>>>> If I am reading the code correctly, durin=
g crossover, if the
>>>>>>> substrates are
>>>>>>>> the same (i.e. all link=
s have the same ID), which is always the
>>>>> case
>>>>>>> in
>>>>>>>> P-N=
EAT, *all* of the link values are taken from either parent1 or
>>>>>>> pare=
nt2.
>>>>>>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some from par=
ent1
>>>>>>> and some
>>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
>>=
>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, right? It=
 will
>>>>>>> always grab
>>>>>>>> the substrate of parent1 or the substrat=
e of parent2.  If I track
>>>>>>> parent and
>>>>>>>> offspring fitness, 10=
0% of the time the child has the exact same
>>>>>>> fitness as
>>>>>>>> one=
 of the two parents.
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT:
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>>=
 I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting offspring.
>>>>>>> =
The odd
>>>>>>>> thing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e. th=
ey are
>>>>>>> never
>>>>>>>> mutated) have the *exact* same fitness of one=
 of their parents
>>>>>>> 98.88% of the
>>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was=
 only 136 orgs out of 12257 that were
>>>>>>> crossed over
>>>>>>>> and not=
 mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would these
>>>>> new
>>>>>>> l=
inks
>>>>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that this is because
>=
>>>> nearly
>>>>>>> every
>>>>>>>> time that there is an extra link that ge=
ts placed in the child,
>>>>> the
>>>>>>> parent
>>>>>>>> that donated that=
 link is also the parent whose weights are being
>>>>>>> grabbed,
>>>>>>>> =
meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent (hence the
>>>>>>> sa=
me
>>>>>>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be much more
>>>=
>>>> disruptive, no?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> As a final test, I did a =
set of hyperneat and pneat runs with the
>>>>>>> default
>>>>>>>> 'MutateOn=
lyProbability' parameter set to .25, so 25% of orgs
>>>>> never
>>>>>>> are=

>>>>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
>>>>=
>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
>>>>> MutateOnlyProbabil=
ity
>>>>>>>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over. Despite =
my
>>>>>>> comments
>>>>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperNE=
AT-noCross, however
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>>> difference was not tremendous (alt=
hough it does seem to be
>>>>>>> statistically
>>>>>>>> significant). For p=
-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
>>>>> this
>>>>>>> is not a
>>>>=
>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends, because if
>>>>>>> c=
rossover does
>>>>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I increase MutateOnlyP=
robability
>>>>> from
>>>>>>> .25 to
>>>>>>>> 1, I have effectively raised =
the mutation rate (only 80% of
>>>>> crossed
>>>>>>> orgs are
>>>>>>>> also=
 mutated).
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Are these the intended consequences of crosso=
ver, or am I missing
>>>>>>> something?
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Cheers,
>>>>>>>>=
 Jeff Clune
>>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State Univer=
sity
